An Indiana University extension class
in an audio-visual course may be offered
ih Huntington High School next fall if
enough teachers are interested in it.
L. C. Larson, director of the Audio-
Visual Center at IU, replied to an in¬
quiry from Mr. Day to the effect that it
will likely be possible to schedule a
class if a request is made soon enough.
Courses might be offered in R^23 Uti¬
lization of Audio-Visual Materials or
P31i3 Preparation of Inexpensive Instruc¬
tional Materials, each with graduate
credit.
To learn if there is enough interest
to assure a class, a blank is provided
j George Rogers Clark

The class will be open to teachers in
the city schools, in the county schools,
and in nearby cities, who may find it
convenient to come to Huntington. The
course to be offered will depend upon the
choices indicated by. teachers.
Interest in audio-visual courses has
been increased because of the ruling of
the state commission requiring coordi¬
nators with five semester hours in audio¬
visual work to qualify the building for
certification.
